titleStmt.title: The Lamentable Tragedy of Titus Andronicus.

respStmt.name: Payge Temple with homgraphing and regularising by Alexis Antonia

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Titus Andronicus; a noble Roman Marcus Andronicus; brother to Titus Lucius; son to Titus Saturnius; son to the late Emperor of Rome Tamora; Queen of the Goths Demetrius; son to Tamora Aaron; a Moor Chiron; son to Tamora Quintus; son to Titus Martius; son to Titus Mutius; son to Titus Lavinia; daughter to Titus Ensemble Publius; son to Marcus Alarbus; son to Tamora Bassianus; brother to Saturnius Young Lucius Clown Nurse Aemilius; a noble Roman First Goth Second Goth Third Goth Captain Messenger Tribunes Roman Lord

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

div2.head: Actus Primus. Scoena Prima.
div2.stage: Flourish. Enter the Tribunes and Senators aloft And then enter Saturninus and his Followers at one doore, and Bassianus and his Followers at the other, with Drum & Colours.

sp.speaker: Saturninus.
sp.l: NOble Patricians, Patrons of my right,
Defend the justice of my Cause with Arms.
And Countrymen, my loving Followers,
Plead my Successive Title with your Swords.
I was the first born Son, that was the last
That wore the Imperial Diadem of Rome:
Then let my Fathers Honours live in me,
Nor wrong mine Age with this indignity.

sp.speaker: Bassianus.
sp.l: Romans, Friends, Followers,
Favourers of my Right:
If ever Bassianus, Caesars Son,
Were gracious in the eyes of Royal Rome,
Keep then this passage to the Capital:
And suffer not Dishonour to approach
the imperial Seat to Virtue: consecrate
To Justice, Continence, and Nobility:
But let Desert in pure Election shine;
And Romans, fight for Freedom in your Choice.

div2.stage: Enter Marcus Andronicus aloft with the Crowne.

sp.speaker: Marcus.
sp.l: Princes, that strive by Factions, and by Friends,
Ambitiously for Rule and Empery:
Know, that the people of Rome for whom we stand
A special Party, have by Common voice
In Election for the Roman Empery,
Chosen Andronicus, Surnamed Pious,
For many good and great deserts to Rome.
A Nobler man, a braver Warrior,
Lives not this day within the City Walls.
He by the Senate is accited home
From weary Wars against the barbarous Gothes,
That with his Sons (a terror to our Foes)
Hath yoked a Nation strong, trained up in Arms.
Ten years are spent, since first he undertook
This Cause of Rome, and chastised with Arms
Our Enemies pride. Five times he hath returned
Bleeding to Rome, bearing his Valiant Sons
In Coffins from the Field.
And now at last, laden with Honours Spoils,
Returns the good Andronicus to Rome,
Renowned Titus, flourishing in Arms.
Let us entreat, by Honour of his Name,
Whom (worthily) you would have now succeed,
And in the Capital and Senates right,
Whom you pretend to Honour and Adore,
That you withdraw you, and abate your Strength,
Dismiss your Followers, and as Suitors should,
Plead your Deserts in Peace and Humbleness.

sp.speaker: Saturnine.
sp.l: How fair the Tribune speaks,
To calm my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bassia.
sp.l: Marcus Andronicus, so I do affy
In thy uprightness and Integrity:
And so I Love and Honour thee, and thine,
Thy Noble Brother Titus, and his Sons,
And Her (to whom my thoughts are humbled all)
Gracious Lauinia, Rome's rich Ornament,
That I will here dismiss my loving Friends:
And to my Fortunes, and the Peoples Favour,
Commit my Cause in balance to be weighed.

sp.speaker: Saturnine.
sp.l: Friends, that have been
Thus forward in my Right,
I thank you all, and here Dismiss you all,
And to the Love and Favour of my Country,
Commit myself, my Person, and the Cause:
Rome, be as just and gracious unto me,
As I am confident and kind to thee.
Open the Gates, and let me in.

sp.speaker: Bassia.
sp.l: Tribunes, and me, a poor Competitor.

div2.stage: Flourish.They go vp into the Senat house. Enter a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Romans make way: the good Andronicus,
Patron of Virtue, Rome's best Champion,
Successful in the Battles that he fights,
With Honour and with Fortune is returned,
From whence he circumscribed with his Sword,
And brought to yoke the Enemies of Rome.

div2.stage: Sound Drummes and Trumpets. And then enter two of Titus Sonnes; After them, two men bearing a Coffin couered with blacke, then two other Sonnes. After them, Titus Andronicus, and then Tamora the Queene of Gothes, & her two Sonnes Chiron and Demetrius, with Aaron the Moore, and others, as many as can bee: They set downe the Coffin, and Titus speakes.

sp.speaker: Andronicus.
sp.l: Hail Rome:
Victorious in thy Mourning Weeds:
Lo as the Bark that hath discharged his fraught,
Returns with precious lading to the Bay,
From whence at first she weighed her Anchorage:
Cometh Andronicus bound with Laurel bows,
To resalute his Country with his tears,
Tears of true joy for his return to Rome,
Thou great defender of this Capital,
Stand gracious to the Rites that we intend.
Romans, of five and twenty Valiant Sons,
Half of the number that King Priam had,
Behold the poor remains alive and dead!
These that Survive, let Rome reward with Love:
These that I bring unto their latest home,
With burial amongst their Ancestors.
Here Gothes have given me leave to sheath my Sword:
Titus unkind, and careless of thine own,
Why sufferest thou thy Sons unburied yet,
To hover on the dreadful shore of Styx?
Make way to lay them by their Brethren.
There greet in silence as the dead are wont,
And sleep in peace, slain in your Countries wars:
O sacred receptacle of my joys,
Sweet Cell of virtue and Nobility,
How many Sons of mine hast thou in store,
That thou wilt never render to me more?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Give us the proudest prisoner of the Gothes,
That we may hew his limbs, and on a pile
Ad manus fratrum, sacrifice his flesh:
Before this earthly prison of their bones,
That so the shadows be not unappeased,
Nor we disturbed with prodigies on earth.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I give him you, the Noblest that Survives,
The eldest Son of this distressed Queen.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Stay Roman Brethren, gracious Conqueror,
Victorious Titus, rue the tears I shed,
A Mothers tears in passion for her son:
And if thy Sons were ever dear to thee,
O think my sons to be as dear to me.
Sufficeth not, that we are brought to Rome
To beautify thy Triumphs, and return
Captive to thee, and to thy Roman yoke,
But must my Sons be slaughtered in the streets,
For Valiant doings in their Countries cause?
O! If to fight for King and Common-weal,
Were piety in thine, it is in these:
Andronicus, stain not thy Tomb with blood.
Wilt thou draw near the nature of the Gods?
Draw near them then in being merciful.
Sweet mercy is Nobility's true badge,
Thrice Noble Titus, spare my first born son.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Patient yourself Madam, and pardon me.
These are the Brethren, whom you Gothes beheld
Alive and dead, and for their Brethren slain,
Religiously they ask a sacrifice:
To this your son is marked, and die he must,
To appease their groaning shadows that are gone.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Away with him, and make a fire straight,
And with our Swords upon a pile of wood,
Let us hew his limbs till they be clean consumed.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: O cruel irreligious piety.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Was ever Scythia half so barbarous?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Oppose me Scythia to ambitious Rome,
Alarbus goes to rest, and we survive,
To tremble under Titus threatening looks,
Then Madam stand resolved, but hope withal,
The self same Gods that armed the Queen of Troy
With opportunity of sharpe revenge
Upon the Thracian Tyrant in his Tent,
May favour Tamora the Queen of Gothes,
(When Gothes were Gothes, and Tamora was Queen)
To quit the bloody wrongs upon her foes.

div2.stage: Enter the Sonnes of Andronicus againe.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: See Lord and Father, how we have performed
Our Roman rights, Alarbus limbs are lopped,
And entrails feed the sacrificing fire,
Whose smoke like incense doth perfume the sky.
Remaineth nought but to inter our Brethren,
And with loud Larums welcome them to Rome.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Let it be so, and let Andronicus
Make this his latest farewell to their souls.
sp.stage: Flourish. Then Sound Trumpets, and lay the Coffins in the Tombe.
sp.l: In peace and Honour rest you here my Sons,
Rome's readiest Champions, repose you here in rest,
Secure from worldly chances and mishaps:
Here lurks no Treason, here no envy swells,
Here grow no damned grudges, here are no storms,
No noise, but silence and Eternal sleep,
In peace and Honour rest you here my Sons.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: In peace and Honour, live Lord Titus long,
My Noble Lord and Father, live in Fame:
Lo at this Tomb my tributary tears,
I render for my Brethren's Obsequies:
And at thy feet I kneel, with tears of joy
Shed on the earth for thy return to Rome.
O bless me here with thy victorious hand,
Whose Fortune Rome's best Citizens applaud.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Kind Rome,
That hast thus lovingly reserved
The Cordial of mine age to glad my heart,
Lauinia live, outlive thy Fathers days:
And Fames eternal date for vertues praise.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Long live Lord Titus, my beloved brother,
Gracious Triumpher in the eyes of Rome.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Thanks Gentle Tribune,
Noble brother Marcus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And welcome Nephews from successful wars,
You that survive and you that sleep in Fame:
Fair Lords your Fortunes are all alike in all,
That in your Countries service drew your Swords.
But safer Triumph is this Funeral Pomp,
That hath aspired to Solons Happiness,
And Triumphs over chance in honours bed.
Titus Andronicus, the people of Rome,
Whose friend in justice thou hast ever been,
Send thee by me their Tribune and their trust,
This Parliament of white and spotless Hue,
And name thee in Election for the Empire,
With these our late deceased Emperor's Sons:
Be Candidatus then, and put it on,
And help to set a head on headless Rome.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: A better head her Glorious body fits,
Than his that shakes for age and feebleness:
What should I don this Robe and trouble you,
Be chosen with proclamations today,
Tomorrow yield up rule, resign my life,
And set abroad new business for you all.
Rome I have been thy Soldier forty years,
And led my Countries strength successfully,
And buried one and twenty Valiant Sons,
Knighted in Field, slain manfully in Arms,
In right and Service of their Noble Country:
Give me a staff of Honour for mine age.
But not a Sceptre to control the world,
Upright he held it Lords, that held it last.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Titus, thou shalt obtain and ask the Empery.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Proud and ambitious Tribune canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Patience Prince Saturninus.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Romans do me right.
Patricians draw your Swords, and sheath them not
Till Saturninus be Rome's Emperor:
Andronicus would thou wert shipped to hell,
Rather than rob me of the peoples hearts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Proud Saturnine, interrupter of the good
That Noble minded Titus means to thee.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Content thee Prince, I will restore to thee
The peoples hearts, and wean them from themselves.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Andronicus, I do not flatter thee
But Honour thee, and will do till I die:
My Faction if thou strengthen with thy Friend?
I will most thankful be, and thanks to men
Of Noble minds, is Honourable Meed.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: People of Rome, and Noble Tribunes here,
I ask your voices and your Suffrages,
Will you bestow them friendly on Andronicus?

sp.speaker: Tribunes.
sp.l: To gratify the good Andronicus,
And Gratulate his safe return to Rome,
The people will accept whom he admits.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Tribunes I thank you, and this sure I make,
That you Create your Emperor's eldest son,
Lord Saturnine, whose Vertues will I hope,
Reflect on Rome as Tytans Rays on earth,
And ripen Justice in this Common-weal:
Then if you will elect by my advice,
Crown him, and say: Long live our Emperor.

sp.speaker: Mar. An.
sp.l: With Voices and applause of every sort,
Patricians and Plebeians we Create
Lord Saturninus Rome's Great Emperor.
And say, Long live our Emperor Saturnine.

div2.stage: A long Flourish till they come downe.

sp.speaker: Satu.
sp.l: Titus Andronicus, for thy Favours done,
To us in our Election this day,
I give thee thanks in part of thy Deserts,
And will with Deeds requite thy gentleness:
And for an Onset Titus to advance
Thy Name, and Honourable Family,
Lauinia will I make my Empress,
Rome's Royal Mistress, Mistress of my heart
And in the Sacred Pathan her espouse:
Tell me Andronicus doth this motion please thee?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: It doth my worthy Lord, and in this match,
I hold me Highly Honoured of your Grace,
And here in sight of Rome, to Saturnine,
King and Commander of our Common-weal,
The Wide-worlds Emperor, do I Consecrate,
My Sword, my Chariot, and my Prisoners,
Presents well Worthy Rome's Imperial Lord:
Receive them then, the Tribute that I owe,
Mine Honours Ensigns humbled at my feet.

sp.speaker: Satu.
sp.l: Thanks Noble Titus, Father of my life,
How proud I am of thee, and of thy gifts
Rome shall record, and when I do forget
The least of these unspeakable Deserts,
Romans forget your Fealty to me.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Now Madam are your prisoner to an Emperor,
To him that for you Honour and your State,
Will use you Nobly and your followers.

sp.speaker: Satu.
sp.l: A goodly Lady, trust me of the Hue
That I would choose, were I to choose anew:
Clear up Fair Queen that cloudy countenance,
Though chance of war
Hath wrought this change of cheer,
Thou comest not to be made a scorn in Rome:
Princely shall be thy usage every way.
Rest on my word, and let not discontent
Daunt all your hopes: Madam he comforts you,
Can make your Greater than the Queen of Gothes?
Lauinia you are not displeased with this?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Not I my Lord, sith true Nobility,
Warrants these words in Princely courtesy.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Thanks sweet Lauinia, Romans let us go:
Ransomless here we set our Prisoners free,
Proclaim our Honours Lords with Trump and Drum.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Lord Titus by your leave, this Maid is mine.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: How sir? Are you in earnest then my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Aye Noble Titus, and resolved withal,
To do myself this reason, and this right.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Suum cuiquam, is our Roman Justice,
This Prince in Justice seizeth but his own.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And that he will and shall, if Lucius live.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Traitors avaunt, where is the Emperor's Guard?
Treason my Lord, Lauinia is surprised.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Surprised, by whom?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: By him that justly may
Bear his Betrothed, from all the world away.

sp.speaker: Muti.
sp.l: Brothers help to convey her hence away,
And with my Sword I will keep this door safe.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Follow my Lord, and I will soon bring her back.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: My Lord you pass not here.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: What villain Boy, barrest me my way in Rome?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Help Lucius help.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord you are unjust, and more than so,
In wrongful quarrel, you have slain your son.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Nor thou, nor he are any sons of mine,
My sons would never so dishonour me.
Traitor restore Lauinia to the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dead if you will, but not to be his wife,
That is another's lawful promised Love.

div2.stage: Enter aloft the Emperour with Tamora and her two sonnes, and Aaron the Moore.

sp.speaker: Empe.
sp.l: No Titus, no, the Emperor needs her not,
Nor her, nor thee, nor any of thy stock:
I will trust by Leisure him that mocks me once.
Thee never: nor thy Traitorous haughty sons,
Confederates all, thus to dishonour me.
Was none in Rome to make a stale
But Saturnine? Full well Andronicus
Agree these Deeds, with that proud brag of thine,
That saidst, I begged the Empire at thy hands.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: O monstrous, what reproachful words are these?

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: But go thy ways, go give that changing piece,
To him that flourished for her with his Sword:
A Valiant son in-law thou shalt enjoy:
One, fit to bandy with thy lawless Sons,
To ruffle in the Common-wealth of Rome.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: These words are Razors to my wounded heart.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: And therefore lovely Tamora Queen of Gothes,
That like the stately Thebe amongst her Nymphs
Dost over-shine the Gallantest Dames of Rome,
If thou be pleased with this my sudden choice,
Behold I choose thee Tamora for my Bride,
And will Create thee Empress of Rome.
Speak Queen of Goths dost thou applaud my choice?
And here I swear by all the Roman Gods,
Sith Priest and Holy-water are so near,
And Tapers burn so bright, and everything
In readiness for Hymeneus stand,
I will not resalute the streets of Rome,
Or clime my Palace, till from forth this place,
I lead espoused my Bride along with me,

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: And here in sight of heaven to Rome I swear,
If Saturnine advance the Queen of Gothes,
She will a Hand-maid be to his desires,
A loving Nurse, a Mother to his youth.

sp.speaker: Satur.
sp.l: Ascend Fair Queen,
Panthean Lords, accompany
Your Noble Emperor and his lovely Bride,
Sent by the heavens for Prince Saturnine,
Whose wisdom hath her Fortune Conquered,
There shall we Consummate our Spousal rites.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I am not bid to wait upon this Bride:
Titus when wert thou wont to walk alone,
Dishonoured thus and Challenged of wrongs?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Titus see! O see what thou hast done!
In a bad quarrel, slain a Virtuous son.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: No foolish Tribune, no: No son of mine,
Nor thou, nor these Confederates in the deed,
That hath dishonoured all our Family,
Unworthy brother, and unworthy Sons.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: But let us give him burial as becomes:
Give Mutius burial with our Brethren.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Traitors away, he rest's not in this Tomb:
This Monument five hundred years hath stood,
Which I have Sumptuously re-edified:
Here none but Soldiers, and Rome's Servitors,
Repose in Fame: None basely slain in brawls,
Bury him where you can, he comes not here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord this is impiety in you,
My Nephew Mutius deeds do plead for him,
He must be buried with his brethren.
And shall, or him we will accompany.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: And shall! What villain was it spake that word?
He that would vouched it in any place but here.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: What would you bury him in my despite?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No Noble Titus, but entreat of thee,
To pardon Mutius, and to bury him.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Marcus, Even thou hast stroke upon my Crest,
And with these Boys mine Honour thou hast wounded,
My foes I do repute you every one.
So trouble me no more, but get you gone.

sp.speaker: 1.Sonne.
sp.l: He is not himself, let us withdraw.

sp.speaker: 2.Sonne.
sp.l: Not I tell Mutius bones be buried.

div2.stage: The Brother and the sonnes kneele.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Brother, for in that name doth nature plead.

sp.speaker: 2.Sonne.
sp.l: Father, and in that name doth nature speak.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Speak thou no more if all the rest will speed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Renowned Titus more than half my soul.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dear Father, soul and substance of us all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Suffer thy brother Marcus to inter
His Noble Nephew here in vertues nest,
That died in Honour and Lauinia's cause.
Thou art a Roman, be not barbarous:
The Greeks upon advice did bury Aiax
That slew himself: And Laertes son,
Did graciously plead for his Funerals:
Let not young Mutius then that was thy joy,
Be barred his entrance here.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Rise Marcus, rise,
The dismallest day is this that ere I saw,
To be dishonoured by my Sons in Rome:
Well, bury him, and bury me the next.

div2.stage: They put him in the Tombe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: There lie thy bones sweet Mutius with thy friends
Till we with Trophies do adorn thy Tomb.
No man shed tears for Noble Mutius,
He lives in Fame, that died in vertues cause.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord to step out of these sudden dumps,
How comes it that the subtle Queen of Gothes,
Is of a sudden thus advanced in Rome?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: I know not Marcus: but I know it is,
(Whether by devise or no) the heavens can tell,
Is she not then beholding to the man,
That brought her for this high good turn so far?
Yes, and will Nobly him remunerate.

div2.stage: Flourish. Enter the Emperor, Tamora, and her two sons, with the Moore at one doore. Enter at the other doore Bassianus and Lauinia with others.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: So Bassianus, you have played your prize,
God give you joy sir of your Gallant Bride.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And you of yours my Lord: I say no more,
Nor wish no less, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Traitor, if Rome have law, or we have power,
Thou and thy Faction shall repent this Rape.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Rape call you it my Lord, to cease my own,
My true betrothed Love, and now my wife?
But let the laws of Rome determine all,
Meanwhile I am possessed of that is mine.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: It is good sir: you are very short with us,
But if we live, we will be as sharpe with you.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: My Lord, what I have done as best I may,
Answer I must, and shall do with my life,
Only thus much I give your Grace to know,
By all the duties that I owe to Rome,
This Noble Gentleman Lord Titus here,
Is in opinion and in honour wronged,
That in the rescue of Lauinia,
With his own hand did slay his youngest Son,
In zeal to you, and highly moved to wrath.
To be controlled in that he frankly gave:
Receive him then to favour Saturnine,
That hath expressed himself in all his deeds,
A Father and a friend to thee, and Rome.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Prince Bassianus leave to plead my Deeds,
It is thou, and those, that have dishonoured me,
Rome and the righteous heavens be my judge,
How I have loved and Honoured Saturnine.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: My worthy Lord if ever Tamora,
Were gracious in those Princely eyes of thine,
Then hear me speak indifferently for all:
And at my suit (sweet) pardon what is past.

sp.speaker: Satu.
sp.l: What Madam, be dishonoured openly,
And basely put it up without revenge?

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Not so my Lord,
The Gods of Rome for-fend,
I should be Author to dishonour you.
But on mine honour dare, I undertake
For good Lord Titus innocence in all:
Whose fury not dissembled speaks his griefs:
Then at my suit look graciously on him,
Loose not so noble a friend on vain suppose,
Nor with sour looks afflict his gentle heart.
My Lord, be ruled by me, be won at last,
Dissemble all your griefs and discontents,
You are but newly planted in your Throne,
Lest then the people, and Patricians too,
Upon a just survey take Titus part,
And so supplant us for ingratitude,
Which Rome reputes to be a heinous sin.
Yield at entreats, and then let me alone:
I will find a day to massacre them all,
And race their faction, and their family,
The cruel Father, and his traitorous sons,
To whom I sued for my dear sons life.
And make them know what it is to let a Queen.
Kneel in the streets, and beg for grace in vain.
Come, come, sweet Emperor, (come Andronicus)
Take up this good old man, and cheer the heart,
That dies in tempest of thy angry frown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rise Titus, rise,
My Empress hath prevailed.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: I thank your Majesty,
And her my Lord.
These words, these looks,
Infuse new life in me.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Titus, I am incorporate in Rome,
A Roman now adopted happily.
And must advise the Emperor for his good,
This day all quarrels die Andronicus.
And let it be mine honour good my Lord,
That I have reconciled your friends and you.
For you Prince Bassianus, I have past
My word and promise to the Emperor,
That you will be more mild and tractable.
And fear not Lords:
And you Lauinia,
By my advice all humbled on your knees,
You shall ask pardon of his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.l: We do,
And vow to heaven, and to his Highness,
That what we did, was mildly, as we might,
Tendering our sisters honour and our own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That on mine honour here I do protest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away and talk not, trouble us no more.

sp.speaker: Tamora.
sp.l: Nay, nay,
Sweet Emperor, we must all be friends,
The Tribune and his Nephews kneel for grace,
I will not be denied, sweetheart look back.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Marcus,
For thy sake and thy brothers here,
And at my lovely Tamora's entreats,
I do remit these young men's heinous faults.
Stand up: Lauinia, though you left me like a churl,
I found a friend, and sure as death I swear,
I would not part a Bachelor from the Priest.
Come, if the Emperor's Court can feast two Brides,
You are my guest Lauinia, and your friends:
This day shall be a Love-day Tamora.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Tomorrow if it please your Majesty,
To hunt the Panther and the Hart with me,
With horn and Hound,
We will give your Grace Bon jour.

sp.speaker: Satur.
sp.l: Be it so Titus, and Gramercy too.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Now climbeth Tamora Olympus top,
Safe out of Fortunes shot, and sits aloft,
Secure of Thunders crack or lightning flash,
Advanced about pale envy's threatening reach:
As when the golden Sun salutes the morn,
And having gilt the Ocean with his beams,
Gallops the Zodiac in his glistering Coach,
And over-looks the highest peering hills:
So Tamora
Upon her wit doth earthly honour wait,
And virtue stoops and trembles at her frown.
Then Aaron arm thy heart, and fit thy thoughts,
To mount aloft with thy Imperial Mistress,
And mount her pitch, whom thou in triumph long
Hast prisoner held, fettered in amorous chains,
And faster bound to Aarons charming eyes,
Than is Prometheus tied to Caucasus.
Away with slavish weeds, and idle thoughts,
I will be bright and shine in Pearl and Gold,
To wait upon this new made Empress.
To wait said I? To wanton with this Queen,
This Goddess, this Semerimis, this Queen,
This Siren, that will charm Rome's Saturnine,
And see his shipwreck, and his Common-weals.
Hollo, what storm is this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Chiron thy years wants wit, thy wit wants edge
And manners to intrude where I am graced,
And may for aught thou knowest affected be.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Demetrius, thou doest overween in all,
And so in this, to bear me down with braves,
It is not the difference of a year or two
Makes me less gracious, or thee more fortunate:
I am as able, and as fit, as thou,
To serve, and to deserve my Mistress grace,
And that my sword upon thee shall approve,
And plead my passions for Lauinia's love.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Clubs, clubs, these lovers will not keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why Boy, although our mother (unadvised)
Gave you a dancing Rapier by your side,
Are you so desperate grown to threat your friends?
Go to: have your Lath glued within your sheath,
Till you know better how to handle it.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Meanwhile sir, with the little skill I have,
Full well shalt thou perceive how much I dare.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Aye Boy, grow ye so brave?

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Why how now Lords?
So near the Emperor's Palace dare you draw,
And maintain such a quarrel openly?
Full well I wot, the ground of all this grudge.
I would not for a million of Gold,
The cause were known to them it most concerns.
Nor would your noble mother for much more
Be so dishonoured in the Court of Rome:
For shame put up.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Not I, till I have sheathed
My rapier in his bosom, and withal
Thrust these reproachful speeches down his throat,
That he hath breathed in my dishonour here.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: For that I am prepared, and full resolved,
Foul spoken Coward,
That thunderest with thy tongue,
And with thy weapon nothing darest perform.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Away I say.
Now by the Gods that warlike Gothes adore,
This pretty brabble will undo us all:
Why Lords, and think you not how dangerous
It is to set upon a Princes right?
What is Lauinia then become so loose,
Or Bassianus so degenerate,
That for her love such quarrels may be broached,
Without controlment, Justice, or revenge?
Young Lords beware, and should the Empress know,
This discord ground, the music would not please.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I care not I, knew she and all the world,
I love Lauinia more than all the world.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: Youngling,
Learn thou to make some meaner choice,
Lauinia is thine elder brothers hope.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Why are ye mad? Or know ye not in Rome,
How furious and impatient they be,
And cannot brooke Competitors in love?
I tell you Lords, you do but plot your deaths,
By this devise.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Aaron, a thousand deaths would I propose,
To achieve her whom I do love.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: To achieve her, how?

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Why, makest thou it so strange?
She is a woman, therefore may be wooed,
She is a woman, therefore may be won,
She is Lauinia therefore must be loved.
What man, more water glideth by the Mill
Than wots the Miller of, and easy it is
Of a cut loaf to steal a shive we know:
Though Bassianus be the Emperor's brother,
Better than he have worn Vulcans badge.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Aye, and as good as Saturnius may.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Then why should he despair that knows to court it
With words, fair looks, and liberality:
What hast not thou full often struck a Do,
And borne her cleanly by the Keepers nose?

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Why then it seems some certain snatch or so
Would serve your turns.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Aye so the turn were served.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Aaron thou hast hit it.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Would you had hit it too,
Then should not we be tired with this ado:
Why hark ye, hark ye, and are you such fools,
To square for this? Would it offend you then?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Faith not me.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Nor me, so I were one.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: For shame be friends, & join for that you jar:
It is policy, and stratagem must do
That you affect, and so must you resolve,
That what you cannot as you would achieve,
You must perforce accomplish as you may:
Take this of me, Lucrece was not more chaste
Than this Lauinia, Bassianus love,
A speedier course this lingering languishment
Must we pursue, and I have found the path:
My Lords, a solemn hunting is in hand.
There will the lovely Roman Ladies troop:
The Forest walks are wide and spacious,
And many unfrequented plots there are,
Fitted by kind for rape and villainy:
Single you thither then this dainty Do,
And strike her home by force, if not by words:
This way or not at all, stand you in hope.
Come, come, our Empress with her sacred wit
To villainy and vengeance consecrate,
Will we acquaint with all that we intend,
And she shall file our engines with advice,
That will not suffer you to square yourselves,
But to your wishes height advance you both.
The Emperor's Court is like the house of Fame,
The palace full of tongues, of eyes, of ears:
The Woods are ruthless, dreadful, deaf, and dull:
There speak, and strike brave Boys, & take your turns.
There serve your lusts, shadowed from heavens eye,
And revel in Lauinia's Treasury.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thy counsel Lad smells of no cowardice.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Sij fas aut nefas, till I find the streams,
To cool this heat, a Charm to calm their fits,
Per Stigia per manes Vehor.

div2.stage: Enter Titus Andronicus and his three sonnes, making a noyse with hounds and hornes, and Marcus.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: The hunt is up, the morn is bright and gray,
The fields are fragrant, and the Woods are green,
Uncouple here, and let us make a bay,
And wake the Emperor, and his lovely Bride,
And rouse the Prince, and ring a hunters peal,
That all the Court may echo with the noise.
Sons let it be your charge, as it is ours,
To attend the Emperor's person carefully:
I have been troubled in my sleep this night,
But dawning day new comfort hath inspired.

div2.stage: Heere a cry of houndes, and winde hornes in a peale, then Enter Saturninus, Tamora, Bassianus, Lauinia, Chiron, Demetrius, and their Attendants.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Many good morrows to your Majesty,
Madam to you as many and as good.
I promised your Grace, a Hunters peal.

sp.speaker: Satur.
sp.l: And you have rung it lustily my Lords,
Somewhat too early for new married Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Lauinia, how say you?

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: I say no:
I have been awake two hours and more.

sp.speaker: Satur.
sp.l: Come on then, horse and Chariots let us have,
And to our sport: Madam, now shall ye see,
Our Roman hunting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have dogs my Lord,
Will rouse the proudest Panther in the Chase,
And clime the highest Promontary top.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: And I have horse will follow where the game
Makes way, and runs likes Swallows over the plain

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Chiron we hunt not we, with Horse nor Hound
But hope to pluck a dainty Do to ground.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: He that had wit, would think that I had none,
To bury so much Gold under a Tree,
And never after to inherit it.
Let him that thinks of me so abjectly,
Know that this Gold must coin a stratagem,
Which cunningly effected, will beget
A very excellent piece of villainy:
And so repose sweet Gold for their unrest,
That have their Alms out of the Empress Chest.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: My lovely Aaron,
Wherefore lookest thou sad,
When everything doth make a Gleeful boast?
The Birds chant melody on every bush,
The Snake lies rolled in the cheerful Sun,
The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind,
And make a checkered shadow on the ground:
Under their sweet shade, Aaron let us sit,
And whilst the babbling Echo mocks the Hounds,
Replying shrilly to the well tuned-Horns,
As if a double hunt were heard at once,
Let us sit down, and mark their yelping noise:
And after conflict, such as was supposed.
The wandering Prince and Dido once enjoyed,
When with a happy storm they were surprised,
And Curtained with a Counsel-keeping Cave,
We may each wreathed in the others arms,
(Our pastimes done) possess a Golden slumber,
Whiles Hounds and Horns, and sweet Melodious Birds
Be unto us, as is a Nurses Song
Of Lullaby, to bring her Babe asleep.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Madam,
Though Venus govern your desires,
Saturne is Dominator over mine:
What signifies my deadly standing eye,
My silence, and my Cloudy Melancholy,
My fleece of Woolly hair, that now uncurls,
Even as an Adder when she doth unroll
To do some fatal execution?
No Madam, these are no Venerial signs,
Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,
Blood, and revenge, are Hammering in my head.
Hark Tamora, the Empress of my Soul,
Which never hopes more heaven, than rests in thee,
This is the day of Doom for Bassianus;
His Philomel must loose her tongue today,
Thy Sons make Pillage of her Chastity,
And wash their hands in Bassianus blood.
Seest thou this Letter, take it up I pray thee,
And give the King this fatal plotted Scroll,
Now question me no more, we are espied,
Here comes a parcel of our hopeful Booty,
Which dreads not yet their lives destruction.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Ah my sweet Moore:
Sweeter to me than life.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: No more great Empress, Bassianus comes,
Be cross with him, and I will go fetch thy Sons
To back thy quarrel whatsoever they be.

sp.speaker: Bassi.
sp.l: Whom have we here?
Rome's Royal Empress,
Unfurnished of our well beseeming troop?
Or is it Dian habited like her,
Who hath abandoned her holy Groves,
To see the general Hunting in this Forest?

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Saucy controller of our private steps:
Had I the power, that some say Dian had,
Thy Temples should be planted presently.
With Horns, as was Acteons, and the Hounds
Should drive upon his new transformed limbs,
Unmannerly Intruder as thou art.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: Under your patience gentle Empress,
It is thought you have a goodly gift in Horning,
And to be doubted, that your Moore and you
Are singled forth to try experiments:
Ioue shield your husband from his Hounds today,
It is pity they should take him for a Stag.

sp.speaker: Bassi.
sp.l: Believe me Queen, your swarthy Cymerion,
Doth make your Honour of his bodies Hue,
Spotted, detested, and abominable.
Why are you sequestered from all your train?
Dismounted from your Snow-white goodly Steed,
And wandered hither to an obscure plot,
Accompanied with a barbarous Moore,
If foul desire had not conducted you?

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: And being intercepted in your sport,
Great reason that my Noble Lord, be rated
For Sauciness, I pray you let us hence,
And let her joy her Raven coloured love,
This valley fits the purpose passing well.

sp.speaker: Bassi.
sp.l: The King my Brother shall have notice of this.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: Aye, for these slips have made him noted long,
Good King, to be so mightily abused.

sp.speaker: Tamora.
sp.l: Why I have patience to endure all this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How now dear Sovereign
And our gracious Mother,
Why doth your Highness look so pale and wan?

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Have I not reason think you to look pale.
These two have ticed me hither to this place,
A barren, detested vale you see it is.
The Trees though Summer, yet forlorn and lean,
Overcome with Moss, and baleful Mistletoe.
Here never shines the Sun, here nothing breeds,
Unless the nightly Owl, or fatal Raven:
And when they showed me this abhorred pit,
They told me here at dead time of the night,
A thousand Fiends, a thousand hissing Snakes,
Ten thousand swelling Toads, as many Urchins,
Would make such fearful and confused cries,
As any mortal body hearing it,
Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.
No sooner had they told this hellish tale,
But strait they told me they would bind me here,
Unto the body of a dismal yew,
And leave me to this miserable death.
And then they called me foul Adulteress,
Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms
That ever ear did hear to such effect.
And had you not by wondrous fortune come,
This vengeance on me had they executed:
Revenge it, as you love your Mothers life,
Or be ye not henceforth called my Children.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: This is a witness that I am thy Son.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And this for me,
Struck home to show my strength.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: I come Semeramis, nay Barbarous Tamora.
For no name fits thy nature but thy own.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Give me thy poniard, you shall know my boys
Your Mothers hand shall right your Mothers wrong.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Stay Madam here is more belongs to her,
First thrash the Corn, then after burn the straw:
This Minion stood upon her chastity,
Upon her Nuptial vow, her loyalty.
And with that painted hope, braves your Mightiness,
And shall she carry this unto her grave?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And if she do,
I would I were an Eunuch,
Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,
And make his dead Trunk-Pillow to our lust.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: But when ye have the honey we desire,
Let not this Wasp outlive us both to sting.

sp.speaker: Chir.
sp.l: I warrant you Madam we will make that sure:
Come Mistress, now perforce we will enjoy,
That nice-preserved honesty of yours.

sp.speaker: Laui
sp.l: O Tamora, thou bearest a woman face.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: I will not hear her speak, away with her.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: Sweet Lords entreat her hear me but a word.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: Listen fair Madam, let it be your glory
To see her tears, but be your heart to them,
As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: When did the Tigers young-ones teach the dam?
O do not learn her wrath, she taught it thee,
The milk thou suckest from her did turn to Marble,
Even at thy Teat thou hadst thy Tyranny,
Yet every Mother breeds not Sons alike,
Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.

sp.speaker: Chiro.
sp.l: What,
Wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: It is true,
The Raven doth not hatch a Lark,
Yet have I heard, O could I find it now,
The Lion moved with pity, did endure
To have his Princely paws pared all away.
Some say, that Ravens foster forlorn children,
The whilst their own birds famish in their nests:
O be to me though thy hard heart say no,
Nothing so kind but something pitiful.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: I know not what it means, away with her.

sp.speaker: Lauin.
sp.l: O let me teach thee for my Fathers sake,
That gave thee life when well he might have slain thee:
Be not obdurate, open thy deaf ears.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Hadst thou in person never offended me.
Even for his sake am I pitiless:
Remember Boys I poured forth tears in vain,
To save your brother from the sacrifice,
But fierce Andronicus would not relent,
Therefore away with her, and use her as you will,
The worse to her, the better loved of me.

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: O Tamora,
Be called a gentle Queen,
And with thine own hands kill me in this place,
For it is not life that I have begged so long,
Poor I was slain, when Bassianus died.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: What beggest thou then? fond woman let me go?

sp.speaker: Laui.
sp.l: It is present death I beg, and one thing more,
That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:
O keep me from their worse than killing lust,
And tumble me into some loathsome pit,
Where never man's eye may behold my body,
Do this, and be a charitable murderer.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: So should I rob my sweet Sons of their fee,
No let them satisfy their lust on thee.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Away,
For thou hast staid us here too long.

sp.speaker: Lauinia.
sp.l: No Grace,
No womanhood? Ah beastly creature,
The blot and enemy to our general name,
Confusion fall---

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nay then I will stop your mouth
Bring thou her husband,
This is the Hole where Aaron bid us hide him.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Farewell my Sons, see that you make her sure,
Never let my heart know merry cheer indeed,
Till all the Andronici be made away:
Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moore,
And let my spleenful Sons this Trull deflower.

div2.stage: Enter Aaron with two of Titus Sonnes.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Come on my Lords, the better foot before,
Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit,
Where I espied the Panther fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: My sight is very dull whatever it bodes.

sp.speaker: Marti.
sp.l: And mine I promise you, were it not for shame,
Well could I leave our sport to sleep a while.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: What art thou fallen?
What subtle Hole is this,
Whose mouth is covered with Rude growing Briers,
Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed-blood,
As fresh as mornings dew distilled on flowers,
A very fatal place it seems to me:
Speak Brother hast thou hurt thee with the fall?

sp.speaker: Martius.
sp.l: O Brother,
With the dismallest object
That ever eye with sight made heart lament.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Now will I fetch the King to find them here,
That he thereby may have a likely guess,
How these were they that made away his Brother.

sp.speaker: Marti
sp.l: Why dost not comfort me and help me out,
From this unhallowed and blood-stained Hole?

sp.speaker: Quintus.
sp.l: I am surprised with an uncouth fear,
A chilling sweat overruns my trembling joints,
My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.

sp.speaker: Marti.
sp.l: To prove thou hast a true divining heart,
Aaron and thou look down into this den,
And see a fearful sight of blood and death.

sp.speaker: Quintus.
sp.l: Aaron is gone,
And my compassionate heart
Will not permit mine eyes once to behold
The thing whereat it trembles by surmise:
O tell me how it is, for never till now
Was I a child, to fear I know not what.

sp.speaker: Marti.
sp.l: Lord Bassianus lies imbrewed here,
All on a heap like to the slaughtered Lamb,
In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: If it be dark, how dost thou know it is he?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Upon his bloody finger he doth wear
A precious Ring, that lightens all the Hole:
Which like a Taper in some Monument,
Doth shine upon the dead man's earthly cheeks,
And shows the ragged entrails of the pit:
So pale did shine the Moon on Pyramus,
When he by night lay bathed in Maiden blood:
O Brother help me with thy fainting hand.
If fear hath made thee faint, as me it hath,
Out of this fell devouring receptacle,
As hateful as Ocitus misty mouth.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Reach me thy hand, that I may help thee out,
Or wanting strength to do thee so much good,
I may be plucked into the swallowing womb,
Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus grave:
I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.

sp.speaker: Martius.
sp.l: Nor I no strength to clime without thy help.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Thy hand once more, I will not loose again,
Till thou art here aloft, or I below,
Thou canst not come to me, I come to thee.

div2.stage: Enter the Emperour, Aaron the Moore.

sp.speaker: Satur.
sp.l: Along with me, I will see what hole is here,
And what he is that now is leapt into it.
Say, who art thou that lately didst descend,
Into this gaping hollow of the earth?

sp.speaker: Marti.
sp.l: The unhappy son of old Andronicus,
Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,
To find thy brother Bassianus dead.

sp.speaker: Satur.
sp.l: My brother dead? I know thou dost but jest,
He and his Lady both are at the Lodge,
Upon the North-side of this pleasant Chase,
It is not an hour since I left him there.

sp.speaker: Marti.
sp.l: We know not where you left him all alive,
But out alas, here have we found him dead.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Where is my Lord the King?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Where is thy brother Bassianus?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound,
Poor Bassianus here lies murthered.

sp.speaker: Tam.
sp.l: Then all too late I bring this fatal writ,
The complot of this timeless Tragedy,
And wonder greatly that man's face can fold,
In pleasing smiles such murderous Tyranny.
And if we miss to meet him handsomely,
Sweet huntsman, Bassianus it is we mean,
Do thou so much as dig the grave for him,
Thou knowest our meaning, look for thy reward
Among the Nettles at the Elder tree:
Which over-shades the mouth of that same pit:
Where we decreed to bury Bassianuss
Do this and purchase us thy lasting friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Tamora, was ever heard the like?
This is the pit, and this the Elder tree,
Look sirs, if you can find the huntsman out,
That should have murthered Bassianus here.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: My gracious Lord here is the bag of Gold.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Two of thy whelps, fell Curs of bloody kind
Have here bereft my brother of his life:
Sirs drag them from the pit unto the prison,
There let them bide until we have devised
Some never heard-of torturing pain for them.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: What are they in this pit,
O wondrous thing!
How easily murder is discovered?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: High Emperor, upon my feeble knee,
I beg this boon, with tears, not lightly shed,
That this fell fault of my accursed Sons,
Accursed, if the faults be proved in them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If it be proved? you see it is apparent,
Who found this Letter, Tamora was it you?

sp.speaker: Tamora.
sp.l: Andronicus himself did take it up.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I did my Lord,
Yet let me be their bail,
For by my Fathers reverent Tomb I vow
They shall be ready at your Highness will,
To answer their suspicion with their lives.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou shalt not bail them, see thou follow me:
Some bring the murthered body, some the murtherers,
Let them not speak a word, the guilt is plain,
For by my soul, were there worse end than death,
That end upon them should be executed.

sp.speaker: Tamo.
sp.l: Andronicus I will entreat the King,
Fear not thy Sons, they shall do well enough.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Come Lucius come,
Stay not to talk with them.

div2.stage: Enter the Empresse Sonnes, with Lauinia, her hands cut off and her tongue cut out, and rausht.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: So now go tell and if thy tongue can speak,
Who it was that cut thy tongue and ravished thee.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Write down thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,
And if thy stumps will let thee play the Scribe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: See how with signs and tokens she can scowl.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Go home,
Call for sweet water, wash thy hands.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash.
And so let us leave her to her silent walks.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If it were my cause, I should go hang myself.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.

div2.stage: Enter Marcus from hunting, to Lauinia.

sp.l: Who is this, my Niece that flies away so fast?
Cousin a word, where is your husband?
If I do dream, would all my wealth would wake me;
If I do wake, some Planet strike me down,
That I may slumber in eternal sleep.
Speak gentle Niece, what stern ungentle hands
Hath lopped, and hewed, and made thy body bare
Of her two branches, those sweet Ornaments
Whose circling shadows, Kings have sought to sleep in
And might not gain so great a happiness
As half thy Love: Why dost not speak to me?
Alas, a Crimson river of warm blood,
Like to a bubbling fountain stirred with wind,
Doth rise and fall between thy Roseate lips,
Coming and going with thy honey breath.
But sure some Tereus hath deflowered thee,
And lest thou shouldest detect them, cut thy tongue.
Ah, now thou turnest away thy face for shame:
And notwithstanding all this loss of blood,
As from a Conduit with their issuing Spouts,
Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titans face,
Blushing to be encountered with a Cloud,
Shall I speak for thee? shall I say it is so?
O that I knew thy heart, and knew the beast
That I might rail at him to ease my mind.
Sorrow concealed, like an Oven stopped,
Doth burn the heart to Cinders where it is.
Fair Philomela she but lost her tongue,
And in a tedious Sampler sowed her mind.
But lovely Niece, that mean is cut from thee,
A craftier Tereus hast thou met withal,
And he hath cut those pretty fingers off,
That could have better sowed than Philomel.
O had the monster seen those Lily hands,
Tremble like Aspen leaves upon a Lute,
And make the silken strings delight to kiss them,
He would not then have touched them for his life.
Or had he heard the heavenly Harmony,
Which that sweet tongue hath made:
He would have dropped his knife and fell asleep,
As Cerberus at the Thracian Poets feet.
Come, let us go, and make thy father blind,
For such a sight will blind a fathers eye.
One hours storm will drown the fragrant meads,
What, will whole months of tears thy Fathers eyes?
Do not draw back, for we will mourn with thee:
O could our mourning ease thy misery.

div2.head: Actus Tertius.
div2.stage: Enter the Iudges and Senatours with Titus two sonnes bound, passing on the Stage to the place of execution, and Titus going before pleading.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Hear me grave fathers, noble Tribunes stay,
For pity of mine age, whose youth was spent
In dangerous wars, whilst you securely slept:
For all my blood in Rome's great quarrel shed,
For all the frosty nights that I have watched,
And for these bitter tears, which now you see,
Filling the aged wrinkles in my cheeks,
Be pitiful to my condemned Sons,
Whose souls is not corrupted as it is thought:
For two and twenty sons I never wept,
Because they died in honours lofty bed.
sp.stage: Andronicus lyeth downe, and the Iudges passe by him.
sp.l: For these, Tribunes, in the dust I write
My hearts deep languor, and my souls sad tears:
Let my tears stanch the earths dry appetite.
My sons sweet blood, will make it shame and blush:
O earth! I will befriend thee more with rain
That shall distill from these two ancient ruins,
Then youthful April shall with all his showers
In summers drought: I will drop upon thee still,
In Winter with warm tears I will melt the snow,
And keep eternal springtime on thy face,
So thou refuse to drink my dear sons blood.
sp.stage: Enter Lucius, with his weapon drawne.
sp.l: O reverent Tribunes, o gentle aged men,
Unbind my sons, reverse the doom of death,
And let me say (that never wept before)
My tears are now prevailing Orators.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: O noble father, you lament in vain,
The Tribunes hear not, no man is by,
And you recount your sorrows to a stone.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Ah Lucius for thy brothers let me plead,
Grave Tribunes, once more I entreat of you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, no Tribune hears you speak.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Why it is no matter man, if they did hear
They would not mark me: o if they did hear
They would not pity me.
Therefore I tell my sorrows bootless to the stones.
Who though they cannot answer my distress,
Yet in some sort they are better than the Tribunes,
For that they will not intercept my tale;
When I do weep, they humbly at my feet
Receive my tears, and seem to weep with me,
And were they but attired in grave weeds,
Rome could afford no Tribune like to these.
A stone is as soft wax,
Tribunes more hard than stones:
A stone is silent, and offendeth not,
And Tribunes with their tongues doom men to death.
But wherefore standest thou with thy weapon drawn?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: To rescue my two brothers from their death,
For which attempt the Judges have pronounced
My everlasting doom of banishment.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: O happy man, they have befriended thee:
Why foolish Lucius, dost thou not perceive
That Rome is but a wilderness of Tigers?
Tigers must prey, and Rome affords no prey
But me and and mine: how happy art thou then,
From these devourers to be banished?
But who comes with our brother Marcus here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Titus, prepare thy noble eyes to weep,
Or if not so, thy noble heart to break:
I bring consuming sorrow to thine age.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Will it consume me? Let me see it then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This was thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Why Marcus so she is.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Aye me this obiect kils me.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Fainthearted boy, arise and look upon her,
Speak Lauinia, what accursed hand
Hath made thee handless in thy Fathers sight?
What fool hath added water to the Sea?
Or brought a faggot to bright burning Troy?
My grief was at the height before thou camest,
And now like Nylus it disdaineth bounds:
Give me a sword, I will chop off my hands too,
For they have fought for Rome, and all in vain:
And they have nursed this woe,
In feeding life:
In bootless prayer have they been held up,
And they have served me to effectless use.
Now all the service I require of them,
Is that the one will help to cut the other:
It is well Lauinia, that thou hast no hands,
For hands to do Rome service, is but vain.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Speak gentle sister, who hath martyred thee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O that delightful engine of her thoughts,
That blabbed them with such pleasing eloquence,
Is torn from forth that pretty hollow cage,
Where like a sweet melodious bird it sung,
Sweet varied notes enchanting every ear.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: O say thou for her,
Who hath done this deed?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O thus I found her straying in the Park,
Seeking to hide herself as doth the Dear
That hath received some unrecurring wound.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: It was my Dear,
And he that wounded her,
Hath hurt me more, than had he killed me dead:
For now I stand as one upon a Rock,
Environed with a wilderness of Sea.
Who marks the waxing tide,
Grow wave by wave,
Expecting ever when some envious surge,
Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.
This way to death my wretched sons are gone:
Here stands my other son, a banished man,
And here my brother weeping at my woes.
But that which gives my soul the greatest spurn,
Is dear Lauinia, dearer than my soul.
Had I but seen thy picture in this plight,
It would have madded me. What shall I do?
Now I behold thy lively body so?
Thou hast no hands to wipe away thy tears,
Nor tongue to tell me who hath martyred thee:
Thy husband he is dead, and for his death
Thy brothers are condemned, and dead by this.
Look Marcus, ah son Lucius look on her:
When I did name her brothers, then fresh tears
Stood on her cheeks, as doth the honey dew,
Upon a gathered Lily almost withered.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Perchance she weeps because they killed her
husband,
Perchance because she knows him innocent.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: If they did kill thy husband then be joyful,
Because the law hath taken revenge on them.
No, no, they would not do so foul a deed,
Witness the sorrow that their sister makes.
Gentle Lauinia let me kiss thy lips,
Or make some signs how I may do thee ease:
Shall thy good Uncle, and thy brother Lucius,
And thou and I sit round about some Fountain,
Looking all downwards to behold our cheeks
How they are stained in meadows, yet not dry
With miry slime left on them by a flood:
And in the Fountain shall we gaze so long,
Till the fresh taste be taken from that clearness,
And made a brine pit with our bitter tears?
Or shall we cut away our hands like thine?
Or shall we bite our tongues, and in dumb shows
Pass the remainder of our hateful days?
What shall we do? Let us that have our tongues
Plot some devise of further miseries
To make us wondered at in time to come.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sweet Father cease your tears, for at your grief
See how my wretched sister sobs and weeps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Patience dear Niece, good Titus dry thine
eyes.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Ah Marcus, Marcus, Brother well I wot,
Thy napkin cannot drink a tear of mine,
For thou poor man hast drowned it with thine own.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Ah my Lauinia I will wipe thy cheeks.

sp.speaker: Ti
sp.l: Mark Marcus mark, I understand her signs,
Had she a tongue to speak, now would she say
That to her brother which I said to thee.
His Napkin with her true tears all bewet,
Can do no service on her sorrowful cheeks.
O what a sympathy of woe is this!
As far from help as Limbo is from bliss,

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Titus Andronicus, my Lord the Emperor,
Sends thee this word, that if thou love thy sons,
Let Marcus, Lucius, or thyself old Titus,
Or any one of you, chop off your hand,
And send it to the King: he for the same,
Will send thee hither both thy sons alive,
And that shall be the ransom for their fault.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: O gracious Emperor, o gentle Aaron.
Did ever Raven sing so like a Lark,
That gives sweet tidings of the Suns uprise?
With all my heart, I will send the Emperor my hand,
Good Aron wilt thou help to chop it off?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Stay Father, for that noble hand of thine,
That hath thrown down so many enemies,
Shall not be sent: my hand will serve the turn,
My youth can better spare my blood than you,
And therefore mine shall save my brothers lives.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which of your hands hath not defended Rome,
And reared aloft the bloody Battleaxe,
Writing destruction on the enemies Castle?
O none of both but are of high desert:
My hand hath been but idle, let it serve
To ransom my two nephews from their death,
Then have I kept it to a worthy end.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Nay come agree, whose hand shall go along
For fear they die before their pardon come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My hand shall go.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: By heaven it shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Sirs strive no more, such withered herbs as these
Are meet for plucking up, and therefore mine.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sweet Father, if I shall be thought thy son,
Let me redeem my brothers both from death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And for our fathers sake, and mothers care,
Now let me show a brothers love to thee.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Agree between you, I will spare my hand.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Then I will go fetch an Axe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But I will use the Axe.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Come hither Aaron, I will deceive them both,
Lend me thy hand, and I will give thee mine,

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: If that be called deceit, I will be honest,
And never whilst I live deceive men so:
But I will deceive you in another sort,
And that you will say ere half an hour pass.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Now stay you strife, what shall be, is dispatched:
Good Aron give his Majesty me hand,
Tell him, it was a hand that warded him
From thousand dangers: bid him bury it:
More hath it merited: That let it have.
As for my sons, say I account of them,
As jewels purchased at an easy price,
And yet dear too, because I bought mine own.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: I go Andronicus, and for thy hand,
Look by and by to have thy sons with thee:
Their heads I mean: O how this villainy
Doth fat me with the very thoughts of it.
Let fools do good, and fair men call for grace,
Aron will have his soul black like his face.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: O here I lift this one hand up to heaven,
And bow this feeble ruin to the earth,
If any power pities wretched tears,
To that I call: what wilt thou kneel with me?
Do then dear heart, for heaven shall hear our prayers,
Or with our sighs we will breath the welkin dim,
And stain the Sun with fog as sometime clouds,
When they do hug him in their melting bosoms.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O brother speak with possibilities,
And do not break into these deep extremes.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Is not my sorrow deep, having no bottom?
Then be my passions bottomless with them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But yet let reason govern thy lament.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: If there were reason for these miseries,
Then into limits could I bind my woes:
When heaven doth weep, doth not the earth overflow?
If the winds rage, doth not the Sea wax mad,
Threatening the welkin with his big swollen face?
And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?
I am the Sea. Hark how her sighs do flow:
She is the weeping welkin, I the earth:
Then must my Sea be moved with her sighs,
Then must my earth with her continual tears,
Become a deluge: overflowed and drowned:
For why, my bowels cannot hide her woes,
But like a drunkard must I vomit them:
Then give me leave, for losers will have leave,
To ease their stomachs with their bitter tongues,

div2.stage: Enter a messenger with two heads and a hand.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Worthy Andronicus, ill art thou repaid,
For that good hand thou sentest the Emperor:
Here are the heads of thy two noble sons.
And here is thy hand in scorn to thee sent back:
Thy griefs, their sports: Thy resolution mocked,
That woe is me to think upon thy woes,
More than remembrance of my fathers death.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Now let hot Aetna cool in Cicilie,
And be my heart an ever-burning hell:
These miseries are more than may be borne.
To weep with them that weep, doth ease some deal,
But sorrow flouted at, is double death.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Ah that this sight should make so deep a wound,
And yet detested life not shrink thereat:
That ever death should let life bear his name,
Where life hath no more interest but to breath.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor heart that kiss is comfortless,
As frozen water to a starved snake.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: When will this fearful slumber have an end?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now farewell flattery, die Andronicus,
Thou dost not slumber, see thy two sons heads,
Thy warlike hands, thy mangled daughter here:
Thy other banished sons with this dear sight
Struck pale and bloodless, and thy brother I,
Even like a stony Image, cold and numb.
Ah now no more will I control my griefs,
Rent off thy silver hair, thy other hand
Gnawing with thy teeth, and be this dismal sight
The closing up of our most wretched eyes:
Now is a time to storm, why art thou still?

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh? it fits not with this hour.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Why I have not another tear to shed:
Besides, this sorrow is an enemy,
And would usurp upon my watery eyes,
And make them blind with tributary tears.
Then which way shall I find Revenges Cave?
For these two heads do seem to speak to me,
And threat me, I shall never come to bliss,
Till all these mischiefs be returned again,
Even in their throats that have committed them.
Come let me see what task I have to do,
You heavy people, circle me about,
That I may turn me to each one of you,
And swear unto my soul to right your wrongs.
The vow is made, come Brother take a head,
And in this hand the other will I bear.
And Lauinia thou shalt be employed in these things:
Bear thou my hand sweet wench between thy teeth:
As for thee boy, go get thee from my sight,
Thou art an Exile, and thou must not stay,
Hie to the Gothes, and raise an army there,
And if you love me, as I think you do,
Let us kiss and part, for we have much to do.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Farewell Andronicus my noble Father:
The woefullest man that ever lived in Rome:
Farewell proud Rome, till Lucius come again,
He loves his pledges dearer than his life:
Farewell Lauinia my noble sister,
O would thou wert as thou tofore hast been,
But now, nor Lucius nor Lauinia lives
But in oblivion and hateful griefs:
If Lucius live, he will requite your wrongs,
And make proud Saturnine and his Empress
Beg at the gates like Tarquin and his Queen.
Now will I to the Gothes and raise a power,
To be revenged on Rome and Saturnine.

div2.stage: Enter Andronicus, Marcus, Lauinia, and the Boy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: So, so, now sit, and look you eat no more
Then will preserve just so much strength in us
As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.
Marcus unknit that sorrow-wreathed knot:
Thy Niece and I (poor Creatures) want our hands
And cannot passionate our tenfold grief,
With folded Arms. This poor right hand of mine,
Is left to tyrannize upon my breast.
Who when my heart all mad with misery,
Beats in this hollow prison of my flesh,
Then thus I thump it down.
Thou Map of woe, that thus dost talk in signs,
When thy poor heart beats without rageous beating,
Thou canst not strike it thus to make it still?
Wound it with sighing girl, kill it with groans:
Or get some little knife between thy teeth,
And just against thy heart make thou a hole,
That all the tears that thy poor eyes let fall
May run into that sink, and soaking in,
Drown the lamenting fool, in Sea salt tears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fie brother fie, teach her not thus to lay
Such violent hands upon her tender life.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: How now! Has sorrow made thee dote already?
Why Marcus, no man should be mad but I:
What violent hands can she lay on her life:
Ah, wherefore dost thou urge the name of hands,
To bid Aeneas tell the tale twice over
How Troy was burnt, and he made miserable?
O handle not the theme, to talk of hands,
Lest we remember still that we have none,
Fie, fie, how Frantically I square my talk
As if we should forget we had no hands:
If Marcus did not name the word of hands.
Come, let us fall to, and gentle girl eat this,
Here is no drink? Hark Marcus what she says,
I can interpret all her martyred signs,
She says, she drinks no other drink but tears
Brewed with her sorrow: meshed upon her cheeks,
Speechless complainent, I will learn thy thought:
In thy dumb action, will I be as perfect
As begging Hermits in their holy prayers.
Thou shalt not sigh nor hold thy stumps to heaven,
Nor wink, nor nod, nor kneel, nor make a sign,
But I (of these) will wrest an Alphabet,
And by still practice, learn to know thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Good grandsire leave these bitter deep laments,
Make my Aunt merry, with some pleasing tale.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas, the tender boy in passion moved,
Doth weep to see his grandsires heaviness.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Peace tender Sapling, thou art made of tears,
And tears will quickly melt thy life away.
sp.stage: Marcus strikes the dish with a knife.
sp.l: What doest thou strike at Marcus with knife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: At that that I have killed my Lord, a Fly

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Out on the murderer: thou killest my heart,
Mine eyes cloyed with view of Tyranny:
A deed of death done on the Innocent
Becomes not Titus brother: get thee gone,
I see thou art not for my company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas (my Lord) I have but killed a fly.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: But? How: if that Fly had a father and mother?
How would he hang his slender gilded wings
And buzz lamenting doings in the air,
Poor harmless Fly,
That with his pretty buzzing melody,
Came here to make us merry,
And thou hast killed him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pardon me sir,
It was a black ill-favoured Fly,
Like to the Empress Moore, therefore I killed him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: O, o, o,
Then pardon me for reprehending thee,
For thou hast done a Charitable deed:
Give me thy knife, I will insult on him,
Flattering myself, as if it were the Moore,
Come hither purposely to poison me.
There is for thyself, and that is for Tamira: Ah sirrah,
Yet I think we are not brought so low,
But that between us, we can kill a Fly,
That comes in likeness of a Coalblack Moore.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor man, grief has so wrought on him,
He takes false shadows, for true substances.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Come, take away: Lauinia, go with me,
I will to thy closet, and go read with thee
Sad stories, chanced in the times of old.
Come boy, and go with me, thy sight is young,
And thou shalt read, when mine begin to dazzle.

div2.head: Actus Quartus.
div2.stage: Enter young Lucius and Lauinia running after him, and the Boy flies from her with his bookes vnder his arme.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Help Grandsire help, my Aunt Lauinia,
Follows me everywhere I know not why.
Good Uncle Marcus see how swift she comes,
Alas sweet Aunt, I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stand by me Lucius, do not fear thy Aunt.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: She loves thee boy too well to do thee harm

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Aye when my father was in Rome she did.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What means my Niece Lauinia by these signs?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Fear not Lucius, somewhat doth she mean:
See Lucius see, how much she makes of thee:
Some whether would she have thee go with her.
Ah boy, Cornelia never with more care
Read to her sons, than she hath read to thee,
Sweet Poetry, and Tullies Orator:
Canst thou not guess wherefore she plies thee thus?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My Lord I know not I, nor can I guess,
Unless some fit or frenzy do possess her:
For I have heard my Grandsire say full oft,
Extremity of griefs would make men mad.
And I have read that Hecubae of Troy,
Ran mad through sorrow, that made me to fear,
Although my Lord, I know my noble Aunt,
Loves me as dear as ere my mother did,
And would not but in fury fright my youth,
Which made me down to throw my books, and fly
Causeless perhaps, but pardon me sweet Aunt,
And Madam, if my Uncle Marcus go,
I will most willingly attend your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lucius I will.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: How now Lauinia, Marcus what means this?
Some book there is that she desires to see,
Which is it girl of these? Open them boy,
But thou art deeper read and better skilled,
Come and take choice of all my Library,
And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens
Reveal the damned contriver of this deed.
What book?
Why lifts she up her arms in sequence thus?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think she means that there was more than one
Confederate in the fact, Aye more there was:
Or else to heaven she heaves them to revenge.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Lucius what book is that she tosseth so?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Grandsire it is Ouids Metamorphosis,
My mother gave it me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For love of her that is gone,
Perhaps she culled it from among the rest.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Soft, so busily she turns the leaves,
Help her, what would she find? Lauinia shall I read?
This is the tragic tale of Philomel?
And treats of Tereus treason and his rape,
And rape I fear was root of thine annoy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See brother see, note how she quotes the leaves

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Lauinia, wert thou thus surprised sweet girl,
Ravished and wronged as Philomela was?
Forced in the ruthless, vast, and gloomy woods?
See, see, Aye such a place there is where we did hunt,
(O had we never, never hunted there)
Patterned by that the Poet here describes,
By nature made for murthers and for rapes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O why should nature build so foul a den,
Unless the Gods delight in tragedies?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Give signs sweet girl, for here are none but friends
What Roman Lord it was durst do the deed?
Or slunk not Saturnine, as Tarquin erst,
That left the Camp to sin in Lucrece bed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sit down sweet Niece, brother sit down by me,
Appollo, Pallas, Ioue, or Mercury,
Inspire me that I may this treason find.
My Lord look here, look here Lauinia.
sp.stage: He writes his Name with his staffe, and guides it with feet and mouth.
sp.l: This sandy plot is plain, guide if thou canst
This after me, I have writ my name,
Without the help of any hand at all.
Cursed be that heart that forced us to that shift:
Write thou good Niece, and here display at last,
What God will have discovered for revenge,
Heaven guide thy pen to print thy sorrows plain,
That we may know the Traitors and the truth.

div2.stage: She takes the staffe in her mouth, and guides it with her stumps and writes.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: O do ye read my Lord what she hath writs?
Stuprum, Chiron, Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What, what, the lustful sons of Tamora,
Performers of this heinous bloody deed?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Magni Dominator poli,
Tam lentus audis scelera, tam lentus vides?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O calm thee gentle Lord: Although I know
There is enough written upon this earth,
To stir a mutiny in the mildest thoughts,
And arm the minds of infants to exclaims.
My Lord kneel down with me: Lauinia kneel,
And kneel sweet boy, the Roman Hectors hope,
And swear with me, as with the woeful Fear
And father of that chaste dishonoured Dame,
Lord Iunius Brutus swear for Lucrece rape,
That we will prosecute (by good advice)
Mortal revenge upon these traitorous Gothes,
And see their blood, or die with this reproach.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: It is sure enough, and you knew how.
But if you hunt these Bear-whelps, then beware
The Dam will wake, and if she wind you once,
She is with the Lion deeply still in league.
And lulls him whilst she playeth on her back,
And when he sleeps will she do what she list.
You are a young huntsman Marcus, let it alone:
And come, I will go get a leaf of brass,
And with a Gad of steel will write these words,
And lay it by: the angry Northern wind
Will blow these sands like Sibyls leaves abroad,
And wheres your lesson then. Boy what say you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I say my Lord, that if I were a man,
Their mothers bed-chamber should not be safe,
For these bad bond-men to the yoke of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye that is my boy, thy father hath full oft,
For his ungrateful country done the like.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And Uncle so will I, and if I live.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Come go with me into mine Armoury,
Lucius I will fit thee, and withal, my boy
Shall carry from me to the Empress sons,
Presents that I intend to send them both,
Come, come, thou wilt do thy message, wilt thou not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Aye with my dagger in their bosoms Grandsire:

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: No boy not so, I will teach thee another course,
Lauinia come, Marcus look to my house,
Lucius and I will go brave it at the Court,
Aye marry will we sir, and we will be waited on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O heavens! Can you hear a good man groan
And not relent, or not compassion him?
Marcus attend him in his ecstasy,
That hath more scars of sorrow in his heart,
Than foe-mens marks upon his battered shield,
But yet so just, that he will not revenge,
Revenge the heavens for old Andronicus.

div2.stage: Enter Aron, Chiron and Demetrius at one dore: and at another dore young Lucius and another, with a bundle of weapons, and verses writ vpon them.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Demetrius here is the son of Lucius,
He hath some message to deliver us.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Aye some mad message from his mad Grandfather.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: My Lords, with all the humbleness I may,
I greet your honours from Andronicus,
And pray the Roman Gods confound you both.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Gramercy lovely Lucius, what is the news?
For villany is marked with rape. May it please you,
My Grandsire well advised hath sent by me,
The goodliest weapons of his Armoury,
To gratify your honourable youth,
The hope of Rome, for so he bad me say:
And so I do and with his gifts present
Your Lordships, whenever you have need,
You may be armed and appointed well,
And so I leave you both: like bloody villains.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: What is here? a scroll, & written round about?
Let us see.
Integer vitae scelerisque purus, non egit maury iaculis nec arcus.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O it is a verse in Horace, I know it well.
I read it in the Grammar long ago.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Aye just, a verse in Horace: right, you have it,
Now what a thing it is to be an Ass?
Here is no sound jest, the old man hath found their guilt,
And sends the weapons wrapped about with lines,
That wound (beyond their feeling) to the quick:
But were our witty Empress well afoot,
She would applaud Andronicus conceit:
But let her rest, in her unrest awhile.
And now young Lords, wast not a happy star
Led us to Rome strangers, and more than so;
Captives, to be advanced to this height?
It did me good before the Palace gate,
To brave the Tribune in his brothers hearing.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: But me more good, to see so great a Lord
Basely insinuate, and send us gifts.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Had he not reason Lord Demetrius?
Did you not use his daughter very friendly?

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Aye would we had a thousand Roman Dames
At such a bay, by turn to serve our lust.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A charitable wish, and full of love.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Here lack's but you mother for to say, Amen.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And that would she for twenty thousand more.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Come, let us go, and pray to all the Gods
For our beloved mother in her pains.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Pray to the devils, the gods have given us over.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Why do the Emperors trumpets flourish thus?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Belike for joy the Emperor hath a son.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.l: Soft, who comes here?

div2.stage: Enter Nurse with a blackeaMoore childe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Good morrow Lords:
O tell me, did you see Aaron the Moore?

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Well, more or less, or never a whit at all,
Here Aaron is, and what with Aaron now?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: O gentle Aaron, we are all undone,
Now help, or woe betide thee evermore.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Why, what a caterwauling dost thou keep?
What dost thou wrap and fumble in thine arms?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: O that which I would hide from heavens eye,
Our Empress shame, and stately Rome's disgrace,
She is delivered Lords, she is delivered.

sp.speaker: Aron
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I mean she is brought abed?

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Well God give her good rest,
What hath he sent her?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: A devil.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Why then she is the Devils Dam: a joyful issue.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: A joyless, dismal, black &, sorrowful issue,
Here is the babe as loathsome as a toad,
Amongst the fairest breeders of our clime,
The Empress sends it thee, thy stamp, thy seal,
And bids thee christen it with thy daggers point.

sp.speaker: Aron.
sp.l: Out you whore, is black so base a hue?
Sweet blowze, you are a beauteous blossom sure.

sp.speaker: Deme.
